title: Geoffrey Hilton Bowman
text:
<a href="Group%20Captain">Group Captain</a> Geoffrey Hilton "Beery" Bowman, (2 May 1891 – 25 March 1970) was a British <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> <a href="fighter%20ace">fighter ace</a> credited with 32 victories. After attaining the rank of <a href="major">major</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Corps">Royal Flying Corps</a>, he later became a <a href="group%20captain">group captain</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a>.
Early life.
Bowman was born in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>, England, the son of George Bowman, a physician, and his wife Mary. He was educated at <a href="Haileybury%20College">Haileybury College</a> and <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>.
First World War.
Having served in the <a href="Officers%27%20Training%20Corps">Officers' Training Corps</a>, Bowman was commissioned as a probationary <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the 3rd Battalion, <a href="Royal%20Warwickshire%20Regiment">Royal Warwickshire Regiment</a> on 15 August 1914. After serving with his regiment in France, on 20 March 1916 Bowman was seconded to the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Corps">Royal Flying Corps</a>. He was awarded the <a href="Royal%20Aero%20Club">Royal Aero Club</a>'s Aviator's Certificate No. 7977 on 27 June, and was appointed a flying officer in the RFC two days later.
Bowman joined <a href="No.%2029%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 29 Squadron</a> on 7 July 1916, based at <a href="Abeele">Abeele</a>, flying the <a href="Airco%20DH.2">Airco DH.2</a>. His first victory was against a <a href="Roland%20C.II">Roland C.II</a> two seater, with which he unintentionally collided on 3 September; he turned into its attack, firing away, and the German plane tore away his aileron <a href="kingpost">kingpost</a>. Bowman "babied" his crippled craft home despite its lack of lateral control. His second victory, on 27 September, was a run-away German <a href="observation%20balloon">observation balloon</a> which he downed after finding it drifting over the lines; however he crashed while trying to land alongside the balloon wreckage on <a href="Mount%20Kemmel">Mount Kemmel</a>. On 1 January 1917 he was appointed a <a href="flight%20commander">flight commander</a> with the temporary rank of captain, receiving promotion to the permanent rank of captain on 1 April 1917. On 11 May he was posted to No. 56 Squadron as a flight commander, flying <a href="Royal%20Aircraft%20Factory%20S.E.5">S.E.5</a>. By July he had claimed another five victories. On 23 September Bowman was one of the eight British aces who fought and shot down German ace <a href="Werner%20Voss">Werner Voss</a>. Bowman was awarded the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a> on 14 September, and a bar on 26 October. On 9 February 1918 he was posted to command of <a href="No.%2041%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 41 Squadron</a>. Awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> in March 1918, his final tally at the end of the war in November was one aircraft shared captured, one balloon destroyed, 15 aircraft destroyed and 15 driven 'out of control'. He was awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Flying%20Cross%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Distinguished Flying Cross</a> on 30 May 1919, and the <a href="Croix%20de%20guerre%20%28Belgium%29">Croix de guerre</a> from Belgium in July 1919.
Inter-war career.
In February 1919 Bowman completed the Naval Co-operation Course at <a href="RAF%20Calshot">RAF Calshot</a>. On 7 June he was appointed acting-major, and served as the commander of No. 3 Squadron, Slavo-British Aviation Corps, an Anglo-Russian unit based around <a href="Arkhangelsk">Arkhangelsk</a>, fighting for the <a href="White%20movement">White Russians</a> during the <a href="Russian%20Civil%20War">Russian Civil War</a>. Bowman eventually relinquished his Army commission on joining the Royal Air Force on 1 August 1919, with the rank of flight lieutenant.
Bowman served in India in 1920, and was promoted to squadron leader on 1 January 1921. He served in the <a href="RAF%20Coastal%20Area">RAF Coastal Area</a>, and as a supernumerary at the RAF Depot (Inland Area), before attending the <a href="Central%20Flying%20School">Central Flying School</a> for a flying refresher course before embarking for overseas service on 16 January 1922. He served as the Commanding Officer of <a href="No.%208%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 8 Squadron</a> in <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Iraq">Iraq</a> from 1922 to 1924. He then served on the staff at No. 5 Flying Training School, <a href="RAF%20Sealand">RAF Sealand</a>, in 1925, and from December 1925 attended the <a href="Staff%20College%2C%20Quetta">Staff College, Quetta</a>, and then served at Headquarters RAF India until 1928.
On 21 January 1928 he returned to No. 8 Squadron as Commanding Officer, based in <a href="Aden%20Protectorate">Aden</a>, and on 15 March 1929 <a href="Mentioned%20in%20dispatches">his name was brought to notice</a> by Group Captain <a href="William%20Mitchell%20%28RAF%20officer%29">William Mitchell</a>, commander of <a href="British%20Forces%20Aden">British Forces in Aden</a>, for his "distinguished services rendered in connection with the operations in the Protectorate of Aden during the period June to August 1928". He was promoted to wing commander on 1 January 1929.
On 9 August 1929 Bowman was assigned to Headquarters, Inland Area, for <a href="Air%20Staff%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Air Staff</a> duties. In June 1931 he competed in a race at the annual <a href="Hendon%20Air%20Show">Hendon Air Show</a>, flying an <a href="Armstrong%20Whitworth%20Siskin">Armstrong Whitworth Siskin</a>.
Bowman served as the Commanding Officer of No. 1 Armament Training Camp at <a href="RAF%20Catfoss">RAF Catfoss</a>, Yorkshire, from 1 March 1932, and on 15 November was assigned to the Experimental Section at the <a href="Royal%20Aircraft%20Establishment">Royal Aircraft Establishment</a>, Farnborough, for flying duties. He married Pamela Ward of <a href="Marden%20Hill">Marden Hill</a>, Hertfordshire, on 5 December. From 16 October 1933 he was Commanding Officer of RAF South Farnborough, home of the Royal Aircraft Establishment, the School of Photography, and <a href="No.%204%20Squadron%20RAF">No 4 (Army Co-operation) Squadron</a>.
On 6 August 1934 Bowman was assigned to No. 27 Group Headquarters at <a href="RAF%20Grantham">RAF Grantham</a> for Air Staff duties. Finally, on 20 January 1937, Bowman was placed on the retired list at his own request.
World War II and later life.
Bowman was recalled for active service on 1 September 1939, and served until 15 December 1941 before retiring for a second time. He served on the board of the <a href="Heston%20Aircraft%20Company">Heston Aircraft Company</a> in the 1940 and 1950s.
Group Captain Bowman died on 25 March 1970. His funeral was held at Southwest Middlesex Crematorium, <a href="Hanworth">Hanworth</a>, Middlesex, on 2 April, and a <a href="memorial%20service">memorial service</a> held at <a href="St%20Clement%20Danes">St Clement Danes</a>, <a href="Aldwych">Aldwych</a>, on 17 April.
Awards and citations.
